        Summary:
Tybalt is a character in William Shakespeare's play "Romeo and Juliet". He is the son of Lady Capulet's brother, Juliet's hot-headed first cousin, and Romeo's rival. Tybalt is a skilled swordsman and serves as the story's principal antagonist. He is known for his violent, vengeful, and short-tempered nature, which aligns with the Elizabethan belief in the four humours. Tybalt shares the same name as the character Tibert/Tybalt the "Prince of Cats" in "Reynard the Fox", and this is referenced in the play. The character of Tybalt has been portrayed in various adaptations, including the 1968 film "Romeo and Juliet".
